content:
Ear infections: Causes, symptoms, treatment and prevention

Ear infections are common in both adults and children. This is the largest cause of hearing loss or deafness worldwide.

What is an ear infection?
Otitis is an ear infection that causes inflammation and pain. Inflammation can be accompanied by swelling, ear discharge, foul-smelling ears, and hearing loss.
Ear infections are common and the leading cause of hearing loss or deafness

Common ear infections
MSc.BSc.CKI Truong Tri Tuong, Department of Otorhinolaryngology, Tam Anh General Hospital, Ho Chi Minh City, said that ear infections are classified according to the location of infection in the ear. Common types of ear infections include:
1. Otitis externa
Otitis externa is an acute infection of the skin of the ear canal usually caused by bacteria and fungi. Pseudomonas bacteria are the most common cause of this type of ear infection.
The external ear includes the pinna and the external auditory canal, measured from the eardrum to the outside of the ear.
Otitis externa is divided into types including:
1.1 Acute diffuse otitis externa
May present as a localized boil or diffuse infection of the entire ear canal.
1.2 Ear infections caused by swimming
It is a bacterial infection usually caused by water remaining in the external ear canal for a long time, creating a moist environment for bacteria to grow. This type of ear infection has the English term swimmer's ear, is the most common disease in children and is not contagious.(1)
1.3 Fungus of the external auditory canal
It is a condition in which the outer ear becomes inflamed and infected due to a fungal infection. The most common fungal species that cause diseases of the outer ear are Aspergillus and Candida.
2. Otitis media
Otitis media is an infection in the middle ear. This type of ear infection is most common in preschool-age children.
The middle ear includes the mastoid bone and the tympanic cavity. It is part of the temporal bone, filled with air.
There are three types of otitis media, including:
2.1 Acute otitis media (AOM)
Only occurs for a short period of time, usually no more than 4 weeks, and then goes away on its own.
2.2 Serous otitis media (OME)
This condition occurs when fluid builds up in the middle ear without causing an infection. Serous otitis media usually does not cause fever or ear pain.(2)
2.3 Chronic purulent otitis media (CSOM)
CSOM is a consequence of acute otitis media without complete treatment. This condition includes otitis media and is characterized by persistent secretions from the middle ear through a perforated eardrum.
2.4 Malignant otitis externa
This is a serious osteomyelitis of the temporal bone (usually caused by Pseudomonas bacteria). This condition is relatively rare, occurring in the elderly, diabetics and immunocompromised people.
3. Inner ear infection
Otitis media is an infection of the inner ear. The cause may be due to infection with the flu virus, but it may also be due to an infection spreading from the middle ear inside.
The inner ear includes the cochlea, semicircular canals, and vestibule.
Inner ear infections are divided into two types:
3.1 Labyrinthitis
Labyrinthitis is an infection of the labyrinth of the ear. The labyrinth is a part of the inner ear that helps control hearing and balance. Labyrinthitis is often caused by a viral or bacterial infection.
3.2 Vestibular neuritis
Vestibular neuritis is an infection of the vestibular nerve, often seen after influenza infection. The vestibular nerve is part of the inner ear, helping to transmit nerve signals from the vestibular organ to the brain.

Causes of ear infections
The most common cause of ear infections is bacterial, viral and fungal infections. Among them, the bacteria Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae and cold viruses are the main causes of ear infections.
In addition, ear infections also have risk factors including:
Ear damage; Swimming; Immunodeficiency; Sinusitis; Allergy; Seborrheic dermatitis; Psoriasis; Indigo; Use hearing aids; Ear surgery; Young children have poor ear hygiene (3)
Streptococcus pneumoniae bacterial infection is the leading cause of ear infections

Signs of ear infection
Signs of ear infection are very diverse, in which, some of the most common ear infection symptoms include:
Ear pain; Swollen, red ears; Ear discharge; Ears have a foul odor; Itchy ears; Tinnitus; Hearing loss; Fever
In addition, severe ear infections may include symptoms such as:
Dizzy; Overbalance; Headache pain; Hearing loss

Complications of ear infections
Ear infections can cause many complications ranging from mild to serious. Possible complications include:
Perforated eardrum leads to hearing loss;; Mastoiditis;; Labyrinthitis leads to vestibular disorders with symptoms of imbalance and dizziness;; Facial paralysis due to damage to the facial motor nerve (facial nerve);; Dangerous intracranial complications such as meningitis and intracranial abscess.

How to treat ear infections?
Doctor Truong Tri Tuong said that depending on the type of ear infection, doctors can recommend appropriate treatment methods including medical treatment and surgical treatment.
1. Medical treatment
This method includes ear cleaning, using medications and can be combined with home treatment methods.
Medications commonly used to treat ear infections include ear drops, topical ear medications, antibiotics, and anti-inflammatory medications. In some cases, antifungal medication may be needed if there is evidence of a fungal infection.
The most commonly used medications for ear infections include acetic acid and topical corticosteroids, and antibiotic ear drops such as ciprofloxacin, ofloxacin, or neomycin/polymyxin. Antifungal drugs gentian, cresylate acetate, nystatin, clotrimazole...
2. Be careful when using medicine to treat ear infections in children
The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) recommends the following medications to treat ear infections in children.
Analgesic
Children under 6 months of age: Use only acetaminophen.; Children 6 months and older: Can give acetaminophen or ibuprofen.; Do not give children aspirin because it can cause Reye's syndrome. Reye syndrome is a very serious but rare disease that can damage the liver and brain.
Cough and cold medicine
Children under 4 years old: Parents need to use medicine as prescribed by the doctor. Do not use over-the-counter cough and cold medicine for children because it can cause dangerous side effects for children.; Children 4 years and older: Parents need to talk to their doctor about whether over-the-counter cough and cold medications are safe for children.
Parents should always consult a specialist about any medication used to treat ear infections in children. Only use antibiotics as prescribed by your doctor.
3. Surgical treatment
This is an invasive treatment that involves surgery or procedures. Surgery is the last option when medical treatments are ineffective.
Surgery is often applied to severe cases of ear infections, mainly to resolve complications such as mastoiditis, hearing loss, loss of balance, etc.
4. Ear drum repair surgery
This surgical procedure repairs a perforated eardrum caused by infection and helps prevent future infections, improving hearing. Tympanoplasty is usually performed on patients who do not have an infection or cancer in the ear bones.
The surgical process will use grafts taken from the patient's own body, usually fascia, meniscus or ear cartilage to repair the eardrum. After 6-8 weeks of surgery, patients can improve their hearing ability.
5. Open the tympanic membrane and place a drainage tube
Bilateral tympanostomy and drainage tubes are used for patients who frequently have fluid buildup in the middle ear.
During surgery, the doctor will create a small hole and insert an artificial tube to drain the ear fluid out. The patient can leave the hospital the same day, and the eardrum can heal when the drainage tube falls out on its own, usually a few months after surgery.
6. Drill the mastoid bone
The mastoid bone is the bone behind the ear that connects to the middle ear. The surgeon will make an incision behind the ear to access the mastoid bone. Then, the doctor drills and cleans the mastoid bone to help prevent chronic ear infections.
Doctors from the Department of Ear, Nose and Throat, Tam Anh General Hospital, Ho Chi Minh City, perform tympanic surgery to treat ear infections for patients.

Methods to prevent ear infections
To prevent ear infections, Dr. Tuong advises people to pay attention to the following.
Get flu shots and pneumococcal vaccines to protect against a common cause of middle ear infections, Streptococcus pneumonia.; Always maintain hand hygiene.; Breastfeed your baby exclusively until he or she is 6 months old and continue breastfeeding for at least 12 months.; Do not smoke and avoid exposure to secondhand smoke.; Dry your ears thoroughly after swimming.; Do not share earwax removal or ear cleaning tools; Remove earwax properly to avoid damaging the ear; In immunocompromised patients such as HIV, cancer, and diabetes, ears should be regularly checked to prevent the risk of fungal ear infections.; Avoid flu infection that causes complications affecting the ears; People who use hearing aids or cochlear implants should regularly go to the hospital to check the condition of the device.(4)
Children and adults need to be vaccinated against influenza and pneumococcus to prevent the risk of ear infections. Photo: VNVC Vaccination Center

Some frequently asked questions about ear infections
1. Is ear infection contagious?
If the ear infection is caused by the flu virus, it can cause infection in the community. Preschool-age children often get otitis media due to flu virus infection while going to school.
Swimmer's ear is usually not contagious.
2. Does ear infection cause deafness?
Untreated or improperly treated ear infections for a long time can cause complications such as perforated eardrums, leading to hearing loss or deafness.
Ear infections are common and easy to treat. However, if not intervened promptly, complications of ear infections can affect health, even threaten life, and are difficult to treat. Complications of mastoiditis, labyrinthitis, facial paralysis, and meningitis often require surgical intervention and a very long recovery time. After treatment, the patient's hearing may be affected.
After a week, if the ear infection does not improve, the patient needs to see an Ear, Nose and Throat specialist for diagnosis and treatment.
Because of the potential risks of ear infections, Dr. Truong Tri Tuong advised that people need to pay attention to preventing risk factors that cause the disease. When there are symptoms of ear infection, patients need to see an Ear, Nose and Throat specialist for early and thorough treatment and to prevent dangerous complications. Note: Do not treat with unproven folk methods, do not arbitrarily use drugs without a doctor's prescription because it can lead to drug resistance, making it difficult to treat later.
